title: WSDC Round 3 - Malaysia vs Kenya
description: THW replace human judgment with computer algorithms in criminal sentencing decisions.
motion: THW replace human judgment with computer algorithms in criminal sentencing decisions.

title: Online WSDC - Round 3 - Tanzania vs Syria
description:
The prepared motion for this round is:
This House would replace human judgement with computer algorithms in criminal sentencing decisions.
motion: THW replace human judgment with computer algorithms in criminal sentencing decisions.

argument_units.text: There have been considerable developments in artificial intelligence in recent years. The law, like every area of society and industry, will almost certainly be impacted by artificial intelligence in a considerable manner. Computer technology has in fact infused most parts of legal practice, including document preparation, legal research, and even court filing. Algorithms are also infusing the more complex areas of law, including taxation, social security, and immigration.

Proposition believes that criminal sentencing should not be an exception. Some definitions. Criminal sentencing is when a judge decides on the appropriate punishment after a defendant is convicted or pleads guilty. Human judgment is when humans give up judgment on other human beings. And a computer algorithm, simply put, is a set of instructions designed to perform a specific task. As proposition, we have identified

four main problems in today's debate. One, there is a discrepancy of sentencing for criminals under identical criminal evidence and circumstances. I'll tell you that classism plays a role in the type of sentencing criminal gets. Criminals receive different sentences for crimes committed under the same circumstances to their quality of defense. A judge is more likely to be swayed by a lawyer who enters the courtroom looking all fancy in his $4,000 suit defending a rich entrepreneur when compared to a public defender who walks into the courtroom in defense of a poor farmer. Panel, what you need to note here is that it's more likely that that rich entrepreneur will get a lighter sentence compared to that farmer and note that this is under the same evidence and circumstances. I tell you that this discrepancy exists because of human judgment and perception being a part

of the criminal sentencing process. Harsher and longer punishments for non-violent crimes. We tell you that people who aren't necessarily a threat to society, people who don't necessarily commit violent crimes, face harsher, lengthier, and unjustified sentences because of certain political inferences surrounding that particular crime. Let's take an example of drug possession. A human judge is more likely to be pressured by the societal norms and the environment of drug dealers, the political environment surrounding drugs, harsher retribution than people who commit far more violent crimes. Additionally, there needs to be unnecessary overcrowding of fails when people whose crimes don't necessarily prove that they should be in jail, making the justice system in itself ineffective.

Three, elitist sentencing. We tell you oftentimes, the more influential you are, the more likely you are to receive a lighter sentence. And oftentimes, the outcome of this sentence does not reflect the quality of the crime you've committed. Humans are susceptible and vulnerable to sexual influences and popularity. Let's take an example of Oscar Pistorius, who was popular and highly influential, who was sentenced for just six years for manslaughter. But if that was an ordinary Harry, he would have been imprisoned for life, which is the sentence for manslaughter in most justice systems. So this is actually the perception of humans away from the credibility of the sentencing decision.

And fourth, racial bias. I'll tell you that in societies where there are minorities who are of different nationalities, there's a disproportionate number of minorities getting harsher sentences. Let's take America as an example, where black people are the minority and are receiving harsher sentences compared to the white minority population who are the same crimes committed because of the fact that human judges of these sentences are susceptible and are likely to be swayed by external factors

such as the color of your skin. Now moving on to characterization in terms of one, the purpose of the criminal justice system. The criminal justice system is the reason why the state has four main reasons. One, protect who to optimize social outcomes by decreasing the occurrences of crime three to make sure that there's a swift and fair justice delivering process and four rehabilitation and retribution our world is a world where people feel safe because we optimize the criminal justice system when do we opt to entirely change the civic system one we have to change certain system when the current system becomes ineffective in administering the very thing it was made to administer, which in our case is justice. Three, why just the criminal sentencing decisions part of the justice system and not the entire justice system, right? We tell you the justice system is mainly made up of major parts conviction and sentencing you're okay with human judgment being a part of the conviction process but not the sentencing process say this because when a criminal is yet to be convicted there are a lot of things that go into this that process things such as police investigations and trials these processes have their own policies and regulations that make them as fair and just and effective as possible the whole trial process has a lot of people involved. It's a jury, lawyers and judges. It is a much more inefficient process because it is much harder to influence or sway so many people at once compared to if it is just one or two people, right? But when a criminal is being sentenced, the system starts to become inefficient. Because there's usually two judges involved, or sometimes just one. But when it comes to primary court, it's just one human being that's why it's criminal. So they can be super inefficient in the process. So the point is, couldn't in any way be taken away from the trial process, right? Human retrial and reopening cases become irrelevant because we're only talking about sentences today. How will our mechanism work, right? What info will we put into these algorithms? One, the rule of law. We tell you that statutes and ordinances of that country's legal system will be put in as information we tell you that we're better able to mitigate the circumstances right but we're able to cater to things such as whether a criminal should get a minimum or maximum sentence no matter how different the circumstances of a crime are the rule of law on those circumstances will always be the same to evidence enhance and criminal history of the conduct how. How will this work? It will work by combining large amounts of data with fast processing and intelligent algorithms, allowing the software to learn automatically from practical features in the data. It will work through commands and by finding a pattern of correlation in the data it's been fit. But what is even more unique about it is that it is also good at picking up causation patterns in the data, something a human judge cannot do without falling victim to perceptions and biases. So it is good at identifying the two main principles of a crime, what caused the crime, and are there any correlating patterns in the circumstances of this crime with the law or the evidence, and then use all the data to give out a sentence. Another thing we tell you about computer algorithms is that we're able to score and process so much more information than a human because a human's brain can only score so much information. But additionally, we learn through machine learning machine learning over time they're able to better understand and adapt to the political climate or changing societal trends and norms they're even better able to adapt or make changes to things society bias and discrimination being human is our best attribute but it is also our worst attribute we're susceptible to perception supposed to be their. This stops the effective working justices. Cases are dragged on and on. It also means that sometimes criminals who are flight risk or criminals who are waiting to be tested after being tried without bail have to spend an unnecessary amount of time in jail waiting for the sentencing to be scheduled, which at times takes even around three to four months. So in these instances, a judge who would take a longer amount of time would be eliminated from this situation, while a computer algorithm would be much faster and fairness. We tell you that when computer algorithms are used, even when a criminal opts to appeal to a higher court or to a different court hopes that his sentence will be reduced because another judge may fall victim to his emotions, the algorithm will give the same sentence because there'll be an equal and fair metric for sentencing. title: Online WSDC Round 3 - Croatia (Prop) vs Serbia (Opp)
description: This House would replace human judgement with computer algorithms in criminal sentencing decisions.
motion: THW replace human judgment with computer algorithms in criminal sentencing decisions.

argument_units.text: Hey, everyone. We can all agree that today there is a historical and present discrimination against disenfranchised groups such as people of color, minorities, immigrants, people living in poverty, and so on. This is creating a systematic crisis, and on top of that, a personal prejudice. We can see that today, 33% more respondents in the poll describe white people as intelligent than they did black people. As a result of this preset set of beliefs, people have biases, and their jury judges are people. You can see here an example of the USCC report where black male offenders received sentences on an average 19.1% longer than similarly situated white offenders. This unfair sentencing is made possible by having a non-identified unified criteria for sentencing, and secondly, giving the judges the freedom to adjust sentences at their own intuition.

We would change this for a model by, firstly, changes that we would make to the current justice procedures is that blind fractions such as public disturbance or DUI would simply not be a part of the criminal record, and secondly, this demeanor such as petty thefts would be erased from the criminal record two years after committing the crime, which is already in practice in many states in Europe and Asia.

Now, how does sentencing look like on our side? Firstly, the algorithm has a certain sentencing guidelines that the algorithm has to work according to. And secondly, it takes two factors in consideration, which is firstly, the information about the crime the defender is trying to convict it of. And secondly, the previous criminal record of the defender. Now, I would now note the severity of the criminal record will be crucial because this means that if you steal something worth 50 euros three times, you will be charged the same sentence every time. But if you start, for example, with pedicabs and progress to armed robbery or violence, your sentence will certainly increase. Based on this information, the algorithm will calculate the risk of recidivism. Secondly, whether you need rehabilitation and for how long you will be getting it. And thirdly, what kind of harm and how much harm have you done to the society? And based on this information, the sentence will be made to be appropriate for the crime. Now, I know that the side of opposition will most likely tell you that the accuracy of our algorithm will not be good, but we can see that today there is a trend for improving the accuracy of our algorithm will not be good, but we can see that today there is a trend for improving the accuracy of the data. For example, in April 2020, the best-case identification algorithm had an error rate of 0.08% compared to 4.1% for the leading algorithm in 2014. I'll be able to believe that simply this cannot happen with people because as I live, I gain information, and based on those information, I make my own opinions and make my own biases. And I tell you that certainly no one can come to me and erase a part of my memory in order to change my opinions, to change my biases. So the side of opposition needs to clearly say and prove to you why human judgment will always be better than algorithm. Well, we believe that this switch from human-based sentencing to algorithm sentencing is a natural transition in aim to make our justice system fair and fair, just like we've done in the past, just like we've changed justice system in the past to make it more fair.

Now, in my speech, you will first hear my first argument about ensuring impartial and unified justice system, and in our second speech, you will hear our second argument about preventing further discrimination in the default now going on to my first argument about ensuring impartial and the unified justice system so why is it important to have an impartial justice system is in order for it to be effective this means for everyone to know that they will not be able to find a loophole after they committed a crime and this is deterring people from breaking the law in the first place secondly to make sure that the offenders get balanced and proper retaliation for their act. Thirdly, for victims to be sure that the system is recognizing their suffering and actually giving them closure and a fourthly for people to simply have a trust in the system and provide them a feeling of safety. So let's take a look at why none of this is actually happening on the side of opposition. Why is the current system so imparsha?

This is happening because we are giving the judges so much power. Because judges are giving certain freedom in sentencing to further reduce the sentence if they decide to do so. But because of of structural racism, we can see that black people simply cannot get a stable job. They cannot get good education, and therefore, they're perceived as less reliable. This is the present ethnic and racial bias among judges. We have already explained this to you in the stand. Secondly, judges are biased. They're humans after all. We can see that the likelihood of a favorable judge spikes up to about 65% after the judges had lunch before, had a break for a meal or snack. So the third point about judges having more and more imprinted pictures of Black people as criminals, this is because every day they have trials. Every day they sentence Black people to longer sentences. And the more they perceive them as criminals, the bigger the sentences they give to them. They put them in a box. They put them in a box. And this is because they have their memory, and we can simply not just remove it like we can do as an AI. title: WSDC 2024 Serbia   DAY01 Round06   France vs  Zimbabwe
motion: This house supports the establishment of a Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) over the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY).

title: WSDC 2022 | Semi Final | Hong Kong v Singapore
description:
The speakers have been assigned a position randomly and the speech does not necessarily reflect their view.

Hong Kong (proposition) v Singapore (opposition)

The motion reads:

This house prefers parenting models that adultify teenagers (i.e. giving them more responsibilities and autonomy, assuming higher capacity for independence)to those which emphasize their status and treatment as teenagers (i.e. refraining from giving them adult responsibilities, emphasizing they are legal minors).
motion: This house believes that parents should treat teenagers as adults.

argument_units.text: When children mature and change to become teenagers, parents cannot be static. Otherwise, this is a recipe for conflict and perpetual friction. It is of utmost importance that parents adapt to ensure they allow their teenagers to continue to thrive while still protecting them from the worst of outcomes.

Three arguments Hong Kong will forward. Firstly, how we better family relationships. Secondly, how we better prepare teenagers for the future. Lastly, how we better protect teenagers from the worst of harm. Before that, set up. One, what does the status quo look like currently in terms of parenting models? We see there's currently a mix of both sides parenting model, although our side is gaining more prominence right now. But we have traditionally been more accustomed to viewing teenagers as teens. You view them to be more irrational, that as a parent, you know what's better for them than they do themselves.

Second, what does our parenting model look like on our side? We say adultification looks like a general guidance framework. This obviously adapts differently to different families through trial and error. But generally, here are the main outlines. One, we would give teenagers more freedom on our side. You will likely have more financial autonomy, like a monthly allowance, instead of asking their parents for money on every purchase or having their parents decide whether or not you can buy something. You also probably will be allowed to leave the house more. You have later or laxer curfews. We would also probably assign them more responsibility. This can look like, for example, encouraging your teenagers to gain a summer or part-time job or on a smaller scale. You may have more responsibilities at home to just feeding or cleaning your baby sister, cooking your own food and chores along those lines. Thirdly, then, what is the comparative and their model on Singapore side? We say parents are likely to be stricter with teenagers, such as making a 10 p.m. curfew a hard rule, not allowing them to drink or they face punishment otherwise. We'll concede that you probably also will give them less responsibilities. The bottom line is two models are not only different on what is and isn't allowed, but how parents and children communicate and how they choose to do these things, i.e. on issues like sex. On opposition side, parents likely think these teenagers are too young to do this and therefore ban them from having it with their boyfriend in totality. On our side, parents are less likely to be actively against sex, but they're likely still going to prepare you properly, i.e. they're more likely to teach you how to use a condom right, teach you consent. What are the

incentives of parents on both sides of the house then? We say parents have inclinations to protect their child because most parents want the best for them. Every piece of media and every natural instinct you have as a parent is to be protected. When we hear phrases of parents saying rather than letting themselves be the one, that they would rather let themselves be the one hurt instead of their children. They overweight risk with constant unfounded fear for their children's safety and the image of them as just a kid being built into their heads, do not think they can make good decisions. This implies on both sides. Parents probably won't just throw their hands up entirely and not care about their children. But also, we see physically or significantly emotionally abusive or neglectful parents are probably not in this debate as well, given the type of parents that would do this are likely symmetric. If you don't put too much attention on your teen's development, you probably don't realize which

model you're doing. You don't really care anyways. First argument, how do we better family relationships? Parent-child relationships are extremely important for any teen, but especially for teens who need to navigate through the tumultuous transition to adulthood. Firstly then, in opposition, why are relationships constantly at the risk of getting fractured? Here's the case. This is the reason why. Teenagers are going through a lot of physical and mental changes. They learn more about the world. They understand issues that 10-year-olds probably don't. This also means their preferences are likely to change. So for example, when you are a child, you really don't know what it's like to like to like want to get in to get get into a relationship with someone else. But when you are a teenager, it becomes much more proximate. It is also during this time that there may also be more peer pressure to hang out at night or try out activities like drinking. The freedom to make these decisions on how they spend their time and what they want to do is also something teenagers increasingly want. This desire translates into rebellion because parents continue to treat their children as their teenagers as children. This is inflammatory. This coddling goes against the very desire of teens to be given more independence. Consequently, you get teenagers having to sneak out at night because their friends want them to come out and have screaming matches with their parents the next morning about it. Even if the child doesn't end up sneaking out, there's going to be a lot of friction between parents and children because they want entirely different things. Note that when relationships sour during the teenage years, for many households, it is sometimes irreversible. It becomes hard to go back when you spend years fighting and being frustrated with your parents. Why don't we get better parent-child relationships on our side then? Because we say parents are more likely to communicate maturely with their teenagers rather than patronize them. Opposition's parents likely don't try to justify and have a dialogue with their kids on decisions, because parents still believe that their child is incapable of making rational decisions for major life issues. Instead, the parent tries to teach the child that the parent's opinion is the right one rather than discussed together. Note there's a large difference between scolding your child or actively trying to lecture them versus trying to communicate with them. On opposition, the teenager is more likely to feel like they are being ordered around. On our side, that teenager discusses with their parents who is more likely to listen to them on an equal level. The impact of communicating rather than lecturing is immense. It means the teenager feels hurt and respected instead of frustrated that your parent doesn't seem to believe you can also have a right opinion. Think of a typical parenting scenario. Your teen requests to drink at an after-party after graduation and prom night. You as a parent could bluntly refuse on their side. Many children probably grew up in this kind of household in Asian families when your parents refuse to justify their decisions and just say they know better than you. Or you can take the time and explain to them why it's a bad idea or perhaps against their self-interest to get really drunk at a party and then drive home. By doing this, you as a teen better internalize that your parents aren't just being mean, or more likely going to look out for you. We avoid the frustration in Singapore's world. We avoid this miscommunication and misunderstanding that often happens. The impact of this is twofold. One, that you are less likely to have toxic arguments with your parents that anger everyone. It's not a fun time for any side or any party. But second, this is really important. You are more likely to obey their orders in the first place when you respect them more and understand your parents' decisions more. This means on our side, teenagers are more likely to follow the general guidance as well. Realize how useless Singapore's parental rules are if nobody's going to buy in and follow them on their side. The conclusion is we get far better relationships on our side that also aid a child's development. Before I take the multi-second argument, I'll take that POI. If it is true that parents want to have a good relationship with their child, why is it then that they are unlikely want to explain this in a fairly rational and reasonable way to children in our world when they don't let them do something? Yeah, this is about perception, right? Whether the child believes their parents are trying to lecture them or whether they're believing you're trying to communicate them on legal grounds. Secondly, how we better prepare teenagers for the future. The premise and weighing of this is that the role of a parent extends beyond the first 18 years of a child's life. They must prepare that teenager for the future to ensure once they leave the nest, they are able to thrive. We would rather responsibility and freedom be gradually given to them as opposed to suddenly being thrusted upon them on site Singapore. Why are children very unprepared in opposition's world? Because we say they often get a lot of responsibility thrust onto them the second they leave for college, when they're suddenly given a bank account they now have to manage, when they suddenly do not have parents looking over their shoulder in their dorm rooms. We agree that parents on both sides want their children to be prepared for the future, but it is about the method in which you undertake it.
This also directly responds to their POI. In Singapore's world, a parent might do a quick lecture with their teenager on personal finance right before

they leave. This may be useful, but it's hard for the teenager to manage when they've never had the experience of handling their own money before, of having this trial and error process. This is why Drew is still largely clueless over his money, our second speaker, by the way. On our side, parents give the children a set amount of money during their teenage years, but the child can spend however they like. They're able to guide them when they ask for advice. It's far more likely the greater autonomy is significantly more beneficial. But we see teens in Singapore's world are less likely to know how to navigate the world beyond their childhood bubble, when they were once discouraged from dating but now are given a lot of sexual freedom. They won't know how to go about safe sex, learn the red flags of toxic partners, or understand the impact of what their actions are. Why on our side, comparatively, are we better in preparing teenagers for the future? Because often, one, you allow them to know how to handle themselves better. And you know how to manage your finances in time when you have different responsibilities. When there's a habit of knowing how to cook your own food for themselves and your siblings, you know how to take care of yourself in college much better. But additionally, teenagers do not need parents to constantly motivate and scrutinize them. When you are used to your parents nagging at you for studying for a test, joining a club, or finishing your work, once you get into university, you don't have any of this. You won't have developed your own habits of motivation. You are more likely to academically struggle when you rely on an external source of motivation. You are likely to have a difficult time on their side of the house when you won't on ours. Let's make a preemption quickly, because they may say teenagers are going to make bad choices on our side of the house. But we say often these choices aren't going to be atrocious. Parents on both sides will try to prevent their children from doing the worst of stuff like drugs, from constantly being blackout drunk because this is a health risk and even a crime in many cases. All of this means teenagers are far more prepared for the future in our side of the house. Proposition to decide that cares for a child's development while opposition actively worsens it. Okay. So it's unclear why exactly parents don't have the active incentive to teach these basic skills to teenagers on our side of the house. Before I move on, I thought I heard a POI. See, in that first argument on counterbalancing teenage recklessness, the premise of this argument is that there are two inherent aspects of teenage psychology that make teenagers structurally overestimate their ability to be an adult. First, cognitively, their brains are wired in a way that breeds overconfidence. Neuroscientific research has found that because teenagers have an underdeveloped prefrontal cortex responsible for rational decision-making, teenagers frequently rely on the amygdala to make decisions, which is associated with emotions and impulses. Given that the brain is not consciously aware of how it in itself is wired, teenagers are inherently oblivious to their instinct of overconfidence. The second structural reason is that teenagers are uniquely susceptible to societal pressures because teenage years are a special period of identity formation. Their developing brains are trying to figure out who they are and who they want to be. This fuels an instinctive craving for acceptance and belonging, making them especially vulnerable to peer pressure and popular culture, where shows like Breaking Bad and Sex Education frequently portray teenagers engaging in vice, like for instance, doing drugs, like for instance, having sex. That's why the vast majority of smokers in the world pick up the habit at 17 or younger. The upshot is that teenagers are inherently likely to take on adult responsibilities they cannot handle. It looks like a teenage couple having sex because that's a cornerstone of the adult experience before the girl gets pregnant and is forced to go through the traumatic experience of an abortion. In our world, parents balance against this inherent psychological bias teenagers experience by treating them like their age. I know Proposition has said that teenagers are rebellious, but this doesn't cut into the argument because parents don't just advise their teenagers about what they should do. They take active steps to prevent teenagers from rebelling by monitoring what their teenagers do to implementing, for instance, punishments or curfews. Hence, we uniquely prevent teenagers from making risky decisions that harm themselves in the future because it's very and uniquely hard for teenagers to circumvent these measures on our side of the house. Before I move on to the second argument, happy to take that. The premise is that adulthood is complex, which means that treating a teenager like an adult means exposing teenagers to the full range of complexities of adulthood, not just the joys of having independence, but also the burdens of adult experiences. When we shield teenagers from these burdens because we don't treat them as adults, parents on prop are far more likely to be frank about these struggles because they're key parts of their own adult life. This is devastating for two reasons. While these struggles sound trivial to adults, the fact that children have fewer lived experiences means that there are psychologically huge challenges for them because it's the first time as a teenager you're going through such an experience.
